turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Well, if the Clock People give you any inside information on the end of the world, drop us a postcard.

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: The world isn't going to end, you dummy; I hope you know that much.  But it is going to change. It's going to change drastically, and probably in your lifetime. The Clock People see calamitous earthquakes as the agent of change, and they may be right, since there are a hundred thousand earthquakes a year and major ones are long overdue. But there are far worse catastrophes coming... unless the human race can bring itself to abandon the goals and values of civilization, in other words, unless it can break the consumption habit -- and we are so conditioned to consuming as a way of life that for most of us life would have no meaning without the yearnings and rewards of progressive consumption. It isn't merely that our bad habits will cause global catastrophes, but that our operative political-economic philosophies have us in such a blind crab grip that they prevent us from preparing for the natural disasters that are not our fault. So the apocalyptic shit is going to hit the fan, all right, but there'll be some of us it'll miss. Little pockets of humanity. Like the Clock People. Like you two honeys, if you decide to accept my offer of a lease on Siwash Cave. There's almost no worldwide calamity -- famine, nuclear accident, plague, weather warfare or reduction of the ozone shield -- that you couldn't survive in that cave.

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: Suppose that you bear five or six children with your characteristics. All in Siwash Cave. In a postcatastrophe world, your offspring would of necessity intermarry, forming in time a tribe. A tribe every member of which had giant thumbs. A tribe of Big Thumbs would relate to the environment in very special ways. It could not use weapons or produce sophisticated tools. It would have to rely on its wits and its senses. It would have to live with animals -- and plants! -- as virtual equals. It's extremely pleasant to me to think about a tribe of physical eccentrics living peacefully with animals and plants, learning their languages, perhaps, and paying them the respect they deserve.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: How am I going to be the progenitor of a tribe when I'm living on an isolated ridgetop with Delores?

turns.speaker: CHINK
turns.text: That's your problem.

turns.speaker: HOWARD
turns.text: Where do you live, Miss Hankshaw?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: I'm staying with the Countess.

turns.speaker: HOWARD
turns.text: I know, but where do you reside when you aren't visiting New York?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: I don't.

turns.speaker: HOWARD
turns.text: You don't?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Well, no, I don't reside anywhere in particular. I just keep moving.

turns.speaker: HOWARD
turns.text: A traveler, eh?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: You might say that, although I don't think of it as traveling.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Where are the others?

turns.speaker: HOWARD
turns.text: Oh, Rupert and Carla had a little hassle and went home.

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: Welcome, podner. By God, it's great to have you here. It's an honor. Sorry I took so long getting to you, but we've had a mess of hard work these past few days -- and a heap of planning to do.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Er, you seem to know who I am, and maybe even what I am. Thanks for the breakfast.

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: Oh, I know about Sissy Hankshaw, all right. I've done a little hitchhiking myself. Ah shucks, that's like telling Annie Oakley you're a sharpshooter because you once knocked a tomato can off a stump with a fieldstone. I'd heard tales about you from people I'd meet in jail cells and truckstops. I heard about your, uh, your, ah, your wonderful thumbs, and I heard how you were Jack Kerouac's girl friend...

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: No, I'm afraid that part isn't true. Jack was in awe of me and tracked me down. We spent a night talking and hugging in a corn field, but he was hardly my lover. Besides, I always travel alone.

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: Well, that doesn't matter; that part never interested me anyway. The beatnicks were before my time, and I never got anything outta the hippies but bad dope, clichés and the clap. But the example of your life helped me in my struggle to be a cowgirl.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Tell me about it.

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: About...

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: About being a cowgirl. What's it all about? When you say the word you make it sound like it was painted in radium on the side of a pearl.

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: Cowgirls exist as an image. A fairly common image. The idea of cowgirls especially for little girls prevails in our culture. Therefore, it seems to me, the existence of cowgirls should prevail. Otherwise, they're being fooled. In the Rodeo Hall of Fame in Oklahoma City there are just two cowgirls. Two. And both of 'em are trick-riders. Trick-riding is what cowgirls have almost always done in rodeos. Our society sure likes to see its unconventional women do tricks. That's what prostitutes call it, you know: 'tricking.'

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: You're political, then?

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: No, ma'am. No way. There's girls on the Rubber Rose who are political, but I don't share their views. I got no cowgirl ideology to expound. "Politics is for people who have a passion for changing life but lack a passion for living it."

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: Did that last comment sound too profound to be coming outta my mouth? It's not original. It's something I picked up from the Chink.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Really? The Chink, huh? I've gathered that you sometimes speak with him. What else have you learned from the Chink?

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: Learned from the Chink? Oh my. Ha ha. That's hard to say. We mostly.... Uh, a lot of his talk is pretty goofy.

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: ......Delores zonks out on peyote at least once a week, but so far her Third Vision hasn't happened. Niwetükame, the Mother Goddess has not gotten back in touch with her. Meanwhile she and Debbie are rivaling each other like a couple of crosstown high schools. Tension. Cowgirl tension! What a drag.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: What is Debbie's position?

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: Debbie says that if women are to take charge again, they must do it in the feminine way; they mustn't resort to aggressive and violent masculine methods. She says it is up to women to show themselves better than men, to love men, set good examples for them and guide them tenderly toward the New Age. She's a real dreamer, that Debbie-dear.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: You don't agree with Debbie, then?

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: I wouldn't say that. I expect she's right, ultimately. But I'm with Delores when it comes to fighting for what's mine. I can't understand why Delores is so uptight about the Chink; he could probably teach her a thing or two. Ee! That grass tickles, doesn't it? God knows I love women, but nothing can take the place of a man that fits. Still this is cowgirl territory and I'll stand with Delores and fight any bastards who might deny it. I guess I've always been a scrapper. Look. This scar. Only twelve years old and I was felled by a silver bullet.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: That's Jellybean!

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: FROM MEN, THE WHOOPING CRANE HAS RECEIVED NEITHER LOVE NOR RESPECT. MEN HAVE DRAINED THE CRANE'S MARSHES, STOLEN ITS EGGS, INVADED ITS PRIVACY, POLLUTED ITS FOOD, FOULED ITS AIR, BLOWN IT APART WITH BUCKSHOT.

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: Looks like every time we get together things are in a mess.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: So be it. It looks serious this time, though. All these guns... are you actually prepared to kill and die for whooping cranes?

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: Hell no, the cranes are wonderful, okay, but I'm not in this for whooping cranes. I'm in it for cowgirls. If we cowgirls give in to authority on this crane issue, then cowgirls become just another compromise. I want a finer fate than that -- for me and for every other cowgirl. Better no cowgirls at all than cowgirls compromised.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: How did this business get started, anyhow? Why are the birds nesting here?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: No, I guess not.

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: 'Drugged' is a stupid word.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: But the peyote is obviously affecting their brains. It's made them break a migratory pattern that goes back thousands of years.

turns.speaker: JELLY
turns.text: Every time I tell you that I love you, you flinch. But that's your problem.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: If I flinch when you say you love me, it's both our problems. My confusion becomes your confusion. Students confuse teachers, patients confuse psychiatrists, lovers with confused hearts confuse lovers with clear hearts....

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: Extraordinary!

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: She's obviously that. Jesus! Which would you rather have, a million dollars or one of Sissy's thumbs full of pennies?

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: Oh, you! I'm not talking about her hands. They're difficult to ignore, I confess, but I'm speaking of her whole being. Her whole being is extraordinary. The way she talks, for example. She's so articulate.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: It's high time you realized, honey babe, that a woman doesn't have to give the best years of her life to Radcliffe or Smith in order to speak the English language.

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: Countess. I'm really in a dither. She's turned my head.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Ninety degrees to the left, I hope. How does she feel about you?

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: I think she's disappointed that I'm not more, ah, sort of atavistic. She's got some naive, sentimental notions about Indians. I'm sure she liked me, though; but.... then she left town.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: She always leaves town, you dummy. That doesn't mean anything. What about in bed? How does she like it in bed?

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: How does she like what in bed?

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: Well.... er...

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Shit O dear, Julian. Do you mean to tell me you didn't get it on?

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: Oh, we didn't get it all the way on.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Whose fault was that?

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: I suppose it was mine. Yes, it definitely was my fault.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: What do they do to you boys in those Ivy league schools, anyway? Strap you down and pump the Nature out of you? They can even press the last drop of Nature out of a Mohawk buck. Why, send a shaman or cannibal to Yale for four years and all he'd be fit for would be a desk in the military-industrial complex and a seat in the third row at a Neil Simon comedy. Jesus H.M.S. Christ! If Harvard or Princeton could get hold of the Chink for a couple of semesters they'd turn him into a candidate for the Bow Tie Wing of the Hall of Wimps. Oogie boogie.

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: If we Ivy Leaguers aren't earthy enough to suit you hillbillies, at least we don't go around indulging in racist terms such as 'Chink.' Next thing I know, you'll be calling me 'chief.'

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Chink's the guy's name, for Christ's sake.

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: What guy?

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Aw, he's some old fart holyman who lives in the hills out West. Gives my ranch the creeps and the willies, too. But though he be old and dirty, he's alive, I'll bet, clear down to his toes. They don't have his juice in a jar in New Haven. Well I suppose that I'll have to write Sissy out on the road.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: I'm cold.

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: Here. I'll turn down the air conditioner.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: It's not the air conditioner that's making me cold. Nothing moves in here. Not even your birds.

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Getting dressed. I've got to go.

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: But I don't want you to leave. Please stay. We can go to dinner. I owe you a dinner. And tonight... we can... really make love.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: I have to go, Julian.

turns.speaker: JULIAN
turns.text: Why? Why do you have to go?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: My thumbs hurt. I've made a mistake. I've been negligent. I haven't exercised. I have to hitchhike a little bit every day, no matter what. It's like a musician practicing his scales. When I don't practice, my timing gets off, my thumbs get stiff and sore.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Going north?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: You bet your raggedy white ass I am.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: American Cheese. The king of road food.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Are you in show business?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: I was a successful model once.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: For magazines?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: I was the Yoni Yum feminine-hygiene Dew girl from 1965 to 1970, but got laid off.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: So now you're bummin' around?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Yep.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Hitchhiking?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: I'm the best.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: You're the best?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: When I was younger, I hitchhiked one hundred and twenty-seven hours without stopping, without food or sleep, crossed the continent twice in six days, cooled my thumbs in both oceans and caught rides after midnight on unlighted highways.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Whooee!

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: As I developed, however, I grew more concerned with subtleties and nuances of style. Time in terms of M.P.H. no longer interested me. I began to hitchhike in something akin to geological time: slow, ancient, vast. When I am really moving, stopping car after car after car, moving so freely, so clearly, so delicately that even the sex maniacs and the cops can only blink and let me pass, then I embody the rhythms of the universe. I am in a state of grace.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: To my own special Sissy. Cheers! And welcome. So my letter brought ya flying, eh? Where were you? Salt Lake City? La Conner? Well, I may have a little surprise for you. But first, tell me about yourself. It's been six months, hasn't it? In some circles that's half a year. How are you?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Tired...

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: That's the very first time in the eons that I've known you that I've ever heard you complain. And now you're tired, poor darling.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: A born freak can only go uphill.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Freak, schmeek. Most of us are freaks in one way or another. Try being born a male Russian countess into a white middle class Baptist family in Mississippi and you'll see what I mean.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: I've always been proud of the way nature singled me out. It's the people who have been deformed by society I feel sorry for. I've been steady moving for eleven years and some months. Maybe I should rest up for a spell, I'm not as young as I used to be.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Shit O goodness, you won't be thirty for another year, and you're more beautiful than ever.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Does that mean you might have an assignment for me?

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: You were the Yoni Yum girl from, let's see,  from nineteen sixty-eight through nineteen seventy. You've always smelled so nice. Like a little sister. The irony has just killed me. You, the Dew Girl, one of the few girls who doesn't need Dew. I loath the stink of females! They are so sweet the way God made them, then they start fooling around with men and soon they're stinking. Like rotten mushrooms, like an excessively chlorinated swimming pool, like a tuna fish's retirement party. They all stink. From the Queen of England to Bonanza Jellybean, they stink.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Bonanza Jellybean?

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: What? Oh yes. Tee-hee. Jellybean.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: She's a young thing who works on my ranch. Real name is Sally Jones or something wooden like that. She's cute as a hot fudge taco, and, of course, it takes verve to change one's name so charmingly. But she stinks like a slut just the same.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Your ranch?

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Oh my dear yes, I bought a little ranch out West, sort of a tribute to the women of America who have cooperated with me in eliminating their odor by using my vaginal products, Dew spray mist and Yoni Yum spray powder. A tax write-off, actually.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Sissy, Sissy, blushing bride, you can desist from wearing paths in those forgotten highways. The Countess has arranged a job for you. And what a job...

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: A job for me?

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: I am once more about to make advertising history. And only you, the original Yoni Yum/Dew Girl, could possibly assist me.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: The Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday female deodorant sprays may cause such harmful reactions as blisters, burns and rashes. Although the FDA judges that the reported reactions are not sufficient to justify removal of these products from the market, they are sufficient to warrant the proposed mandatory label warnings.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Shit O dear, that's enough to make me asthmatic. The nerve of those twits. What do they know about female odor? Don't interrupt. Here's my concept. My ranch out West? It's a beauty ranch. Oh, it's got a few head of cattle for atmosphere and tax purposes. But it's a beauty ranch, a place where unhappy women -- divorcees and widows, mainly -- can go to lose weight, remove wrinkles, change their hair styles and pretty themselves up for the next disappointment. My ranch is named the Rubber Rose, after the Rubber Rose douche bag, my own invention, and bless its little red bladder, the most popular douche bag in the world. So get this. It's on the migratory flight path of the whooping cranes. The last flock of wild whooping cranes left in existence. Well, these cranes stop off at my little pond -- Siwash Lake, it's called -- twice a year, autumn and spring, and spend a few days each time, resting up, eating, doing whatever whooping cranes do. I've never seen them, understand, but I hear they're magnificent. Very big specimens -- I mean, huge mothers -- and white as snow, to coin a phrase, except for black tips on their wings and tail feathers, and bright red heads. Now, whooping cranes, in case you didn't know it, are noted for their mating dance. It's just the wildest show in nature. It's probably the reason why birdwatching used to be so popular with old maids and deacons. Picture these rare, beautiful, gigantic birds in full dance -- leaping six feet off the mud, arching their backs, flapping their wings, strutting low to the ground. Dears, it's overwhelming. And picture the birds doing their sex dance on TV. Right there on the home screen, creation's most elaborate sex ritual -- yet clean and pure enough to suit the Pope. With lovely Sissy Hankshaw in the foreground. In a white gown, red hood attached, and big feathery sleeves trimmed in black. In a very subdued imitation of the female whooping crane, she dance/walks over to a large nest in which there sits a can of Yoni Yum. And a can of Dew. Off-camera, a string quartet is playing Debussy. A sensuous voice is reading a few poetic lines about courtship and love. Are you starting to get it? Doesn't it make the hair on your neck stand up and applaud? My very goodness gracious! Grandiose, lyrical, erotic and Girl Scout- oriented; you can't top it. I've hired a crew of experts from Walt Disney Studios, the best wildlife cinematographers around. You're my eternal favorite. Princess Grace herself couldn't be better, not even if she had your personality which she doesn't; Anyway, dear, I'm out of photography now and into water colors. Ah how circuitous conversation is! We're back at the beginning. The exact man I've wanted you to meet is my artist the watercolorist.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: If you don't want me to pose for him, why do you want me to meet him?

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Purely personal. I believe you might enjoy one another.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: But Countess...

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Now, now. Don't get exasperated. I realize that you've always avoided all but the most rudimentary involvements with men, and I might add, you've been wise. Heterosexual relationships seem to lead only to marriage. For men, marriage is a matter of efficient logistics: The male gets his food, bed, laundry, TV, pussy, offspring and creature comforts all under one roof, where he doesn't have to dissipate his psychic energy thinking about them too much, then he is free to go out and fight the battles of life, which is what existence is all about. But for a woman marriage is surrender.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: But here you are, still a virgin -- you are virginal yet, aren't you?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Why, yes, technically. Jack Kerouac and I came awfully close, but he was afraid of me, I think...

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Yes, well, what I'm getting at is that there comes a time when it is psychologically impossible for a woman to lose her virginity. She can't wait too long, you know. Now, there's no reason why you must lose yours. I mean, just ponder it a bit, that's all.

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: What makes you think this watercolorist and I would develop a romantic relationship?

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: I can't be certain that you would. But what have you got to lose?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: Well, okay. I'll try it. I don't see the point in it, but I'll try it. Just for you. It's kind of silly, actually, me going out with an artist in New York City. However...

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Good, good, good... you'll enjoy it, you'll see. Julian is a gentleman.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Sissy, don't play dumb with me! You're a good model but a shitty actress. The cowgirls are involved in this whooping crane disappearance. You know perfectly well they are. Last seen in Nebraska. Didn't make it to Canada. Siwash Lake is between Nebraska and Canada. The cowgirls have possession of Siwash Lake. And who else but Jellybean's wild cunts could possibly conceive of doing something so diabolical as to tamper with the last flock of some nearly extinct birds? How much do you know about it? Have they murdered those cranes the way they murdered my moo cows?

turns.speaker: SISSY
turns.text: I don't know anything about it.

turns.speaker: THE COUNTESS
turns.text: Sissy. You're trying to protect those scuzzy bitches. Well, let your conscience be your guide, as my mommy used to say, but it won't work. Those stinking sluts are going to suffer...

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: Ballast.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I am your best friend. I am a lifesaver and a heartbreaker...

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: That means top-secret, Cooper.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I heard it.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I can see why they sent you along.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: So if the ship didn't blow up, what happened?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: You still need the rope? I thought you were one a those spacemen with ice in ya veins.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: I'd rather be on the rope and not need it than need it and not have it. Now step aside, old man.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: ...do you copy?

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: Uh, yeah Coop, I'm still here.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Shit! Do not do that! Where the fuck are you?

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: I'm in the Second Containment area. It's pitch black in here. There must have been a coolant leak. Man, this shit is everywhere. I can't see a damn thing.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: Holy shit...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Justin?

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: I think I found something...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Time to play Spam in the can.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Don't start with me, Cooper.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Okay, listen up. As you all know by now, we have an addition to our crew. Dr. Weir, this is: Starck, navigation; Smith, pilot, Justin, ship's engineer --

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: You can call him Baby-bear, he loves that...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: This is Cooper, what the hell do you do on this ship, anyway?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: ...cancel our leave and send us out on some bullshit mission...!

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: EVERYBODY SHUT UP! Let the man speak.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: From what?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You're convinced the crew could still be alive? After seven years?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: ...come on, Skipper, I already put my shoes on...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You've had plenty EVA, Coop, it's Justin's turn. Stay on station. If anything happens...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I'll be all over it.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: We have a man down...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Coop, where are you...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: The containment, Second Containment...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Hold on, Coop...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: But Justin...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I'll get him.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Captain Miller, we're ready to repressurize the Clark.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: On my way.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: ...and the gravity drive goes where no man has gone before.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You prep the gravity couches. I'm going to manually arm those explosives.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Will it work?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: It worked for Weir. Prep the tanks.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: You been out there a long time. Trying to break my record?

turns.speaker: SMITH
turns.text: I'd rather spend the next twelve hours Outside than another five minutes in this can. This ship is bad. It watches you.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SMITH
turns.text: You heard me. This ship, it's crazy: trying to go faster'n light, that's like the Tower of Babel.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Shit, Smith, you're going Biblical on me.

turns.speaker: SMITH
turns.text: You know what happened to the Tower of Babel, don't you? It fell down.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: You're sucking too much nitrogen in your mix.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: We'll have to re-route through the port conduit to the APU.

turns.speaker: SMITH
turns.text: What about the accumulator...?

turns.speaker: SMITH
turns.text: It's holding... She's holding...!

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: We're still venting trace gasses, gimme twenty minutes to plug the hole.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Solid as a rock.  Hey, Smith...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Smith, clear that airlock, man, I'm coming in.

turns.speaker: SMITH
turns.text: Roger that.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Damn, Dr. Weir, don't scare us like that. Coffee?

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Coffee.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: No, thank you.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: The Event Horizon only had life support for eighteen months. It seems impossible, but in light of the transmission... I have to think that someone has managed to endure until now.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Skipper, do we get hazard pay for this?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: It was like... nothing was there... and then Justin appeared and the Core... became metal...

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: No, he didn't.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: You weren't there. I saw it.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: Saw what, Mr. Cooper? What did you really see, because what you're describing is not physically possible...

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: I don't know what happened to Justin.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I'm telling you, I saw it...

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: What you saw could have been an optical effect caused by gravitational distortion.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I know what I saw and it wasn't a fucking "optical effect!"

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Is that an offer?

turns.speaker: STARCK
turns.text: It is not.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: What's happening?

turns.speaker: STARCK
turns.text: I don't know, the screens are dead...!

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Let me breathe, let me breathe...

turns.speaker: STARCK
turns.text: You're okay now, it's over...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: How? The Bridge is gone.

turns.speaker: STARCK
turns.text: There must be a way! What about Engineering?

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: Can you shut it down?

turns.speaker: STARCK
turns.text: I don't know the process, Dr. Weir was the expert...

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I don't want to go where the last crew went. I'd rather be dead.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: I'm gonna activate the emergency beacon.

turns.speaker: STARCK
turns.text: Hurry.

turns.speaker: COOPER
turns.text: What...?

turns.speaker: STARCK
turns.text: Run!

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: He's a rescue technician. Peters, medical technician. DJ...

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: Trauma.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: And this is mission specialist Dr. William Weir. We all know where we're going. Dr. Weir is going to tell us why.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: We haven't tested the air yet. It could be contaminated...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: No time. We need whatever's left in our suits to repair the Clark. Like it or not, this is the only oxygen for three billion kilometers.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: How is he?

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: His vitals are stable, but he's unresponsive to stimuli. He might wake up in fifteen minutes. He might not wake up at all.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: Carbon dioxide poisoning produces hallucinations, impaired judgement...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Goddammit, DJ, it was not a hallucination! I saw a man, he was on fire. And then he disappeared.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: To conserve our oxygen, we should severely restrict our activity. Anyone who can should get some sleep.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I don't need sleep, DJ. I need answers.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: He'll live... if we ever make it back.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: We'll make it.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Of course not. Justin just climbed into the airlock because he felt like it. Just one of those things.  I swore I'd never lose another man. I came close today. Real close.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: "Another man?" Who?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I, I tried to go back for him, to save him, but I couldn't get to him in time. The fire... Have you ever seen fire in zero-gravity? It's like a liquid, it slides over everything. It was like a wave breaking over him, a wave of fire. And then he was gone.  I never told anyone until now. But this ship knew, DJ. It knows about the Goliath, it knows about Corrick. It knows our secrets. It knows what we're afraid of.  And now you're going to tell me it's carbon dioxide.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: I've been listening to the transmission. And I think Houston made a mistake in the translation.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: They thought it said, "Liberatis me," "Save me," but it's not "me." It's "tutemet:" "Save yourself."

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: It's not a distress call. It's a warning.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: It gets worse.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: Do you hear it? Right there.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Hear what?

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: It sounds like "ex infera:" "ex," from; "infera," the ablative case of "inferi." "Hell."

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: "Save yourself. From Hell."  What are you saying, are you saying that this ship is possessed?

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: No. I don't believe in that sort of thing.  But if Dr. Weir is right, this ship has passed beyond the boundaries of our universe, of reality. Who knows where this ship has been... What it's seen...  And what it's brought back with it.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: DJ. The Clark's gone. Smith and Cooper are dead.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Weir. He used one of the explosives from the Corridor.

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: Please...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Oh, God, DJ, what do I... how do I...

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: Please... kill...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Oh God...

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: Nothing. It's nothing.

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: What's happening...?

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: A power drain --

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: You didn't hear it? You must have heard it!

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: I've got a pulse, he's alive...

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: Pressure?

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: 90 over 50 and falling... .

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: He's crashing...

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: Intubate, pure oxygen feed, get the nitrogen out of his blood...

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: His peritoneum has ruptured...

turns.speaker: DJ
turns.text: One thing at a time, let's keep him breathing. Start the drip, 15cc's fibrinogen, Christ, he's bleeding out...

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: You wanted to see me, Admiral?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: I apologize for the short notice, Bill, but we've had something come up that requires your immediate attention. Lyle?

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: Incredible... These are the same coordinates before the ship disappeared... this, this happened? This isn't some kind of hoax?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: I wouldn't bring you here on a hoax. Houston confirms the telemetry and I.D. codes.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: It's the Event Horizon. She's come back.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: That ship was lost in deep space, seven years ago. If the Titanic sailed into New York harbor, I'd find it more plausible.  Houston wants Aerospace to send out a search and rescue team, investigate the source of the transmission. If it really is the Event Horizon, they'll attempt a salvage.  We need you to prepare a detailed briefing on the ship's systems for the salvage crew...

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: A written briefing can't possibly anticipate the variables on a mission like this. I have to go with them.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: It's against my better judgement, but I'll run this by the Man downstairs. You'll know my decision by the end of the day.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: Don't thank me, Bill. I'm not doing you any favors.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: It's not that simple.  Lyle, play the recording for Dr. Weir.

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: Navigation Control tried to hail the vessel. This was the only response.

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: You're not seriously considering sending him?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: You don't just dismiss Bill Weir. The man held Oppenheimer's chair at Princeton. If the Event Horizon had worked, he would have gone down in history as the greatest mind in physics since Einstein.

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: The official inquiry blamed Weir's design for the ship's loss.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: That doesn't mean a damn thing. They were looking for a scapegoat and Weir fit the bill. But he's not responsible for what happened to the ship.

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: Does he know that?

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: What's on your mind?

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: He doesn't belong on this mission. Responsible or not, he blames himself. He's too close to it.  And then there's his wife.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: It's been two years since she died. He's over it.

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: Some things you don't get over.

turns.speaker: HOLLIS
turns.text: I want our best people on this. Where's Miller?

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: The Lewis and Clark just returned from patrol in the asteroid belt, she's docked in bay four.

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: What, Justin, what shows you?

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: It won't stop, it goes on and on and on...

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: What does?

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: The dark inside me.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: ...It's inside and it eats and eats until there's nothing left.

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: "The dark inside..."? I don't understand.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: From the Other Place...

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: Oh my god OH MY GOD...

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: Starck!

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: ...is zero. That's what the singularity does: it folds space, so that point A and point B coexist in the same space and time. After the ship passes through this gateway, space returns to normal.  It's called a gravity drive.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: How do you know all this?

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: I built it.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: You've reached the First Containment Seal. The engineering decks are on the other side.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: We still have pressure. The radiation count's steady at 7 millirads an hour.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: Background radiation. Perfectly safe.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: I've reached another containment door. This thing's huge...

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: That's the Second Containment Seal. Beyond that, engineering.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: I'm going in.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: Everything green on my boards, Skipper.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Start the countdown.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Okay. We do it the hard way. Deck by deck, room by room. Starck, deploy the umbilicus. I believe you're up for a walk, Mr. Justin. Go get your bonnet on.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: Yes, sir!

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Justin, finish your sweep.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: Almost done, I just gotta check one thing...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Patch me through to him.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Justin.

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: Skipper, you gotta help me...

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: ...I don't want to die...!

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You're not going to die! Not today! I want you to do exactly as I say and I'm gonna get you out of there, alright?

turns.speaker: JUSTIN
turns.text: But I can't... I gotta get out of here... Skipper, please...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Justin. I won't let you die.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: This is Weir.

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: Dr. Weir, Admiral Hollis would like to see you as soon as possible.

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: Dr. Weir, you have no experience with salvage procedures.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: I designed the ship's propulsion system. I am the only person capable of evaluating the performance of the gravity drive. You can't send a Search and Rescue team out there alone and expect them to succeed. That would be like... like sending an auto- mechanic to work on the shuttle.

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: I can understand your desire to redeem your reputation, Dr. Weir, but it doesn't factor into this.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: This is not about my reputation! This is not about me at all!  The Event Horizon was created for one reason: to go faster than light. Imagine mankind exploring new solar systems, colonizing new worlds. Seven years ago, we didn't just lose the ship and the crew. We lost the dream.  I have to go.

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: Since the initial transmission, there's been no further contact. Just the beacon, every two minutes.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: The crew? Could they still be alive?

turns.speaker: LYLE
turns.text: The ship had life support systems for eighteen months. They're been gone seven years.

turns.speaker: WEIR
turns.text: Someone sent that message. Admiral, you have to put me on that ship.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: What's the hold up?

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: Just loading the last of the CO2 scrubbers.  Good for four months.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I put in for a replacement for you but no one...

turns.speaker: PETERS
turns.text: No, no, its alright. I talked to my ex, he'll keep Denny over Christmas and I'll get him this summer.  Goddam it, Skipper... I haven't seen him in two months.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I am sorry. But now we have to go to work.
